title: The Spiral Manifesto
outcome: An underground essay by Halden, describing society as a spiral of mutual aid and upward movement, is discovered and publicly read. Assemblies debate abandoning punitive justice and BCI obsession, sparking a new, flexible governance based on rotating leadership and personal growth. The spiral idea spreads, shifting public values from surveillance to social mobility.

events.description: An artist collective releases Halden's 'Spiral Manifesto,' suggesting the city rebuild society on cycles of mutual uplift, not surveillance or scoring.
Assemblies convene nightly debates; residents argue over abandoning BCI frameworks entirely, with some neighborhoods piloting rotating leadership roles.
Street courts are paused citywide; testimonial gatherings replace trials as citizens seek reconciliation over punishment, inspired by Halden’s philosophy.
Grassroots leaders announce the formal end of punitive BCI-driven practices; neighborhoods begin testing flexible, volunteer-based governance.
A citywide celebration marks the new 'spiral system,' committing Stenograd to recovery through education, mutual recognition, and rotating civic duty.
